title: Why does every win streak follows a loss streak ?
body:
Literally in my 6 years of playing, this is always the case. It's not even the "you reached your elo so you're losing more". No, I'm playing flex in gold/plat and won 15 out of my 20 games with mehh to decent teammates and then I get into promos for plat 1 and immediately get people who die twice before I even do my both buffs, then proceed to feed for the next 10 mins.
It's not like this is a separate occasion. It ALWAYS happens. Be it on my smurf in silver, flex in gold or diamond solo games. Always.
I don't even get joy from winning few games in a row, because I just wait for that 0/10 bot lane or whoever.

replies.body: Still waiting for that win streak turnaround myself. The loss streak has been real.

Because Riot has rigged the system to be forced 50% winrate and they have enough data to create algorithms that keep people the optimal amount of addicted to keep playing, but not mad enough to quit. The idea is to keep people playing as long and as much as possible so they can have the paid cash skins and other fluff in front of them for maximum exposure.

Edit: If you win too much, which is evident by getting to promos for example, they will put people with low winrate for the elo, or people who have shown consistently weak mental or soft inting or afking/connection issues, to better help keep you down.

This is not to say that these games are unwinnable by default, but they are unwinnable due to the amount of effort needed to win them which is handicapping for you from the jump.

Where Riot fails at the "not mad enough to quit" is with the Boards.

I quit playing after my main account got a 3 day ban for posting in Gameplay about how a OP champ needs to be nerfed down to the level of other similar champs.  The post had 40+ upvotes and a lot of actual discussion about the issue.  But one of the Mods had "Issues" with it and so gave me a 3 day ban.  That was it Im done playing the game.   Nothing that happened IN GAME it was that Im not allowed to bring up concerns on the Boards that did it.

GJ Riot letting the Mods drive away customers.

This is utter bullshit.

Mathematically impossible as well, since it would need to do the same for every player.

The much simpler explanation is MMR and confirmation bias. There is absolutely no reason to make a giant conspiracy that benefits nobody when the truth is that most players make zero effort to improve and naturally land at a 50% winrate with slightly oscillating MMR.

There is zero evidence of rigging that passes even the most basic statistical analysis.

Don't bother giving rational answers. The "rigged ranked games" community here in boards is intellectually at the level of the flat earth society. 

Who cares about statistics when your gut feeling knows what is right.
I have been tilting flat-earther windmills for years, though. Got it down to a science.

> The much simpler explanation is MMR and confirmation bias. There is absolutely no reason to make a giant conspiracy that benefits nobody when the truth is that most players make zero effort to improve and naturally land at a 50% winrate with slightly oscillating MMR.

Actually, the way matchmaking works is parabolic and thats what causes the soft 50% win rate. The way matching _should_ work, and used to work, is that each player would be individually matched with someone of their skill level. 
For example; 
In unbiased matchmaking the first person becomes the keystone.  Say theyre at 150 points, every other player would be around 150, resulting in an _even_ game across large numbers. With this kind of matchmaking, queues are dramatically longer in high ELOs (which is why the matchmaking system was changed in the first place). Game quality, however, is incomparably high and consistency is also much higher because its _actual skill based gameplay_. 

What riot has is a _biased_ matchmaking system for faster queue times. It works by matching 5 people _as a team_ then matching that team against other teams. The team score is similar, much like in unbiased... but heres the kicker; **based on your win rate your score is inflated or deflated, which increases your weight on the team score**. 
Say the teams are 1000. 
Youre a smurf with a 68% win rate and have a weight of _500_. 
Your mid laner on a 55% win rate has a weight of 200. 
Your jungler is on an even 50% at 150. 
Your bot and support duo on a 45% both have 75. 

The parabolic matchmaking on paper is great, but in practice game quality has gone down dramatically. The only way to fix it would be to 'cap' your matchmaking score at say diamond 1 and have the ranks above diamond be actual leader boards where people compete for the highest scores instead of ranks. 
Capping your matchmaking score and giving visual flair to "leaderboard" positions also increases higher ELO skill base, because at that level youre capable of not only analyzing and learning from better players, but also putting it into practice. 
 
  
> There is zero evidence of rigging that passes even the most basic statistical analysis.

Theres no evidence of the contrary as well because this is the kind of data people write programs to collect because its _agonizingly tedious and complex_ , as each individual game requires you to keep track of so many variables.  Over a large enough sample size youre talking about tracking the win rates and performance of thousands of players who interact with your main targets. 

Youd have to be Austin from game theory to do that by hand, or that level of masochist. Youd probably make _mundo_ blush if you pulled it off.

The model which you propose doesn't make any difference compared to an unweighted model since every player is in the same mmr bracket. 

Say you have a team of 5 players:

1) 68% winrate 1501 mmr
2) 55% winrate 1500 mmr
3) 50% winrate 1503 mmr
4) 45% winrate 1504 mmr
5) 45% winrate 1500 mmr

No matter how you weight each player, the team mmr will still be between 1500-1504 which is a very small bracket. 

Remember, the mmr of all 10 players are set to be very close outside of duo queue issues. As a result, "weighing" each team member is completely pointless and makes no difference in game quality. 

https://support-leagueoflegends.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752954-Matchmaking-Guide

>To the matchmaker, a “fair” match can be loosely defined as a match in which each team has a 50% +/-1% chance of winning. In a perfect match, ten individuals with identical MMRs queue at the same time, each having selected a unique position that they’re well-suited for. That situation is incredibly rare depending on who is queueing at the time, so sometimes teams can have very slight skill differences (**on average, no more than 4-5 MMR**).

I am more impressed by some one with 65% out of 200 games then some one at 80 in 10.

Far as I know the system used takes 5 players MMR inside a preset range determined to be good enough then averages them into a team value and pairs vs another team that the same was done. This is done to give it more wiggle room to make quick games like you said. The quickest way is to give 0 consideration to overall K which generates more mismatches.

I  feel matches folks clearly give up and stop trying to win are far to fucking commonplace. Team games are not balanced around people wanting to treat it like a battleroyal and NEXT it.

There's an issue with stat generation for Moba, they have lots of noise where bad and good stats overlap. I don't think its remotely possible to really build a training set for Machine learning that would not be loaded with Bias issues. When you look at the permutations  its a pretty massive #. Then... to adapt information to use for MM?  Champion selection happens in lobby and cant be trusted as a prediction. The individual statistics required for succus vary by kits pretty drastically.

I guess I would try to look at Gold Gaps between teams personally and see how much 1 player contributes... but I don't think that's a be all end all stat.  Would need the Data at hand to really toy around with it.

There is also the issue of a proactive MM system would need to search for correct variables to load games where as reactive systems work faster.

Because humans are really bad with probability. In this case, the biggest factor is probably the ease at which we see patterns. For the purposes of this discussion, let's assume a win has the same probability to happen as a loss.

Getting three wins in a row and then three losses in a row has the exact same chance of happening as win, loss, win, loss, win, loss. Both of those have the same chance of occurring as win, loss, loss, win, win, loss. Whatever pattern of wins and losses you think would represent non-streaks or whatever pattern you would expect from a fair/perfect system has the same chance of occurring as every single other pattern of wins and losses.

And as # of games increases Streaks end up being more likely. Like lets say 5 games played. 2^5=32 (number of possible combinations of results.)

If you write out every combination and check for Streaks you get  a curve that's 5L 4L1W, 3L,3W, 2L3W, 5W.

When you count the strings of games. You find that 10/32 are a streak of a minimum 3 W. Your also looking for Loss streaks as well thou, so you got another 10/32.  So the odds that you see a streak are 20/32 which can be expressed as 62.5%
 
So folks see any match 3 games onwards that breaks the chain as abnormal, then get upset if its cuz a Shitty ally messed the match up. Realistically when you have a terrible teammate your more likely to lose. Vice versa if your losing and get some one whos just demolishes the game.

Look at the On-paper logic for it.
 Your playing a game with 9 identical clones of yourself. All roles and positions are Mirrored. One clone is playing a good deal weaker, all other 9 in the game are close enough to equivalent to be called equal. What team do expect to win?

Your playing a game with 9 clones and all of you are preforming equally in skill, however different champions have been selected. one team has advantages in 3 matchups, be it from personal skill on a kit or inherent kit matchup advantages, and they take the lead. What team do you expect to win?

MMR theory is about Mean averages, So you can view players as dice rolls if you want to use something  observable to see it in practice. 1 game any dice could roll a 1. But overall different face values on dice impact their average. So a string of rolls you would start to see the average over time.  Make a simple game, roll 10 dice in groups of 2. The group of 5 that rolls highest is the "winner".  You can see the impact on a majority when you throw outlier sided dice into the mix. All RNG but clear trends show up overtime.  Add in sorting to increase the frequency of building equal majorities and those trends show up faster. Add in statistical interference for things like, Well D10 can never roll an 11 so clearly this dice face value is X > d10 and the time goes down to sort.

For this simplification, games with 10 D6 have fair equal odds. You throw a different face value into the mix and it skews the odds. If your a D 6 then the outliers impact you outside of your control but If your the outlier You skew the odds every time you roll.

So, if your personal skill is above the majority, your going into games with an advantage. When your roughly the same as everybody that advantage is now gone. So an enemy whos above or a teammate who is subpar sets you back, What team gets them is RNG. Your matches are impacted more by luck when its fair as the closer in skill a majority is the more apparent an outlier becomes.

For league you have player distributions to consider. The enemy has higher odds of getting the worst player in a game if your not it But they also have equal odds to get the best player in the game, if your not it.
